newsitem.title: CHINA: China's communists lease first land to foreigners.
newsitem.headline: China's communists lease first land to foreigners.

text.p: China's communist government has for the first time since it took power in 1949 prised open a ban to lease land to foreign investors in the northwestern Xinjiang region, the China Daily Business Weekly said on Sunday.
The regional government is leasing land-use rights on 16,000 hectares (40,000 acres) of grain and cotton land to try to attract advanced foreign technology, machinery and know-how, it said.

With one-fifth of the land for leasing already cultivated for cereal production and the rest arable land that has yet to be developed, China is clearly keen to use foreign investment on its least-developed land.
About 66,000 hecares of wasteland in the region are in need of agricultural development, the newspaper quoted Hu Guoxuan, deputy director fo the Xinjiang planning commission as saying.
So far Israel, Canada, the United States and Hong Kong have shown interest, Hu said.
Land-use rights can be leased for 30 or 50 years, but investment must be limited to agriculture.
